solution_line_template: First, we find out how many people live in each building. In addition to 10 1 person apartments, as a studio apartment is for a single person, there are {two_person_apartments_count} {people_per_two_person_apartment} person apartments meaning there are {two_person_apartments_count}*{people_per_two_person_apartment}=<<{two_person_apartments_count}*{people_per_two_person_apartment}={people_in_two_person_apartments}>>{people_in_two_person_apartments} people capable of living there.

We then find out how many people can live in the {people_per_four_person_apartment} person apartments by multiplying the number of available {four_person_apartments_count} person apartments by {people_per_four_person_apartment}, performing {four_person_apartments_count}*{people_per_four_person_apartment}={people_in_four_person_apartments} people capable of living there.

So, in 1 building there is room for {studio_apartments_count}+{people_in_two_person_apartments}+{people_in_four_person_apartments}=<<{studio_apartments_count}+{people_in_two_person_apartments}+{people_in_four_person_apartments}={max_occupancy_per_building}>>{max_occupancy_per_building} people.

We multiply this by the {num_buildings} buildings in total, finding a maximum occupancy of {num_buildings}*{max_occupancy_per_building}=<<{num_buildings}*{max_occupancy_per_building}={total_max_occupancy}>>{total_max_occupancy} people

We then multiply this by {occupancy_rate_decimal} to find out how many people would live there at {occupancy_rate_percent}% of maximum occupancy, performing {total_max_occupancy}*{occupancy_rate_decimal}= <<{current_occupancy}={current_occupancy}>>{current_occupancy} people.
